Literature Review: The chemical ecology of floral resources in conservation biological control is a complex and multifaceted field that has garnered significant attention in recent years. In conservation biological control, the intentional provision of flowering plants as food resources for natural enemies of insect pests is a widely used strategy to enhance populations of these beneficial organisms in crop habitats. The attractiveness of these flowering plants to natural enemies is crucial to ensure that they are frequently visited and utilized as food sources. Floral volatiles, which are chemical signals emitted by plants, play a pivotal role in attracting parasitoids to these food resources. The discovery of nectar-inhabiting microbes as hidden players in mediating parasitoid responses to flowering plants has highlighted the complexity of the interactions between plants and parasitoids. Furthermore, because food webs in agroecosystems do not generally stop at the third trophic level, responses of hyperparasitoids to floral resources are also an important consideration. In this review, we provide an overview of floral compounds as semiochemicals from a multitrophic perspective, focusing on the role of floral volatiles, nectar-associated microorganisms, and parasitoid food sources in conservation biological control. We also highlight the remaining questions that need to be addressed to move the field forward.
